thig13.3:1.3: Desire held me back from passing over
thig13.3:1.4: the terrible marsh to the far shore.
thig13.3:2.2: sure that I am captivated by our child.
thig13.3:2.3: I need to cut my bond with Cāpā
thig13.3:3.1: Great hero, will not be upset with me![There is no " in the text, so this could actually still be Kala speaking, perhaps referring to the Buddha]
thig13.3:3.2: Great sage, will not be upset with me!
thig13.3:3.3: For one overcome with anger there is no purity
thig13.3:4.1: I will go away from under her grip! [aḷa = nails ]
thig13.3:4.2: Who would want to live under her grip? ['kodha' appears to be a contraction of 'ko idha' ("who here"). This line literally means "Who will live here in Nāḷā?" as in, "Who would want to live in Nāḷā?"]
thig13.3:5.3: My family and I are under your power.
thig13.3:6.4: for "uḷāra" I recommend a loftier word than 'great'. Perhaps 'magnificent' or 'wonderful'
thig13.3:8.3: or perhaps "How can you go and leave me behind,"
thig13.3:10.1: I take the meaning of 'phala' as figurative, as in 'the fruit of the womb' - so I am inclined to take the compound 'puttaphala' to just be a poetic way of saying 'child'. Therefore I recommend translating this phrase simply as: "And this child of mine,"
thig13.3:17.2: 'anuttara' lit. means "nothing higher". I like "unsurpassable" or "unsurpassed" for that. "to the protector of the world, the unsurpassable one."
thig13.3:17.3: 'padakkhiṇa' can simply mean 'respect' or 'reverence.' So "padakkhiṇaṁ katvā" can just mean "having paid respects" or "having shown reverence". It doesn't necessarily mean "to the right".
thig13.3:20.2: 'atikkama' lit. means "going over" (transcend, or 'cross over', or 'go beyond')
thig13.3:20.3: x - you left out the word 'and' ('caṭṭhaṇgikaṁ' = 'ca aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ')
thig13.3:21.2: As prior noted, I think this means "having shown reverence" or "having paid respects"
